w21zu080wq.directions: 3rd level staircase landing, behind one of the older lecture theatres.
w21zu080wq.name: Serangoon Junior College

w21z39pt8t.name: Ahmad Mosque
w21z39pt8t.remarks: Originally a typical kampung mosque built in 1934 on a piece of land given by a Mr Ahmat Yahya, the mosque has been redeveloped with better facilities.   Located in the Central part of the island, the masjid serves the residents and workers around the area

w21z719ghd.name: Jamae Chulia Mosque
w21z719ghd.remarks: The masjid was a contribution by the Chulian community. Built in 1826, it has gone through several places of renovation and expansion. The building bears the imprint of South Indian architecture in its narrow frontages, which are defined by minaret-style towers. Located in the Central part of the island, it serves office workers and has a capacity of 1500 people. It is one of the few masjids in Singapore, which organizes religious classes in Tamil.

w21z3w65bk.name: Singapore Polytechnic, T21
w21z3w65bk.remarks: Musolla is within view of the basement study corner.

w21zscsu68.name: Al-Ansar Mosque
w21zscsu68.remarks: Al-Ansar with its prominent tower minaret is among the first few masjids built under the Phase One of the Mosque Building Fund. Completed in 1981, the masjid located in the East can fill up to 3000 people at any one time. Located in the heart of the densely populated Bedok housing estate, the masjid offers madrasah classes. It is also one of the few masjids, which organizes religious classes in Tamil and one of the only two masjids with a full-time welfare officer.

w21z3ket7p.directions: EA Engineering - Proceed to Level 7 staircase landing near cafe.
w21z3ket7p.name: EA Engineering, NUS

w21zg4uw0g.name: Nanyang Polytechnic, Blk L
w21zg4uw0g.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Sarong, Al-Quran, Slippers

w21z4kz9j5.directions: B1, Beach Station yellow zone carpark. Take the escalator opposite the information counter to the basement carpark. Turn right and there is a separate room for male & female with a sign stated "Prayer Room". Ablution can be taken at the nearby water point just to the right of the musolla.
w21z4kz9j5.name: Sentosa Island, Beach Station

w21z6v2fxy.directions: Take the lift to level 7 carpark. Out the door (no. 7), turn left and walk straight to the end of carpark (near iSetan sign), near carpark no. 123 & no. 124. Take the pathway near the trubines and it will lead to a "Fire Exit/Staircase 2" door. Open the door to the staircase landing. Musolla is located inside.
w21z6v2fxy.name: Wisma Atria Shopping Centre
w21z6v2fxy.provision: Slippers, Telekung, Prayer Mat, Al-Quran, Fan, Standing separator, Sarong, Chair
w21z6v2fxy.remarks: There is also a small white ceramic basin outside the musolla for ablution. Shared male and female praying area.

w21zt6ke6f.directions: Prayer room is for their staff but customers may ask permission to use it
w21zt6ke6f.name: SPIZE at Bedok

w21z62nug3.name: Al-Amin Mosque
w21z62nug3.remarks: Inspired by Sumatran Minang architecture, this masjid with its brown structure stands out from the high-rise housing estate in Telok Blangah. Located at the Central District, it was built in 1991 with resources from the Mosque Building Fund. With a capacity of 3000, the masjid offers weekend madrasah and weekday classes to a total of 600 children. Islamic knowledge classes are also held during the evening.

w21z37sjrv.address: 10 Kent Ridge Crescent, Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences (S), 119260
w21z37sjrv.directions: FASS AS4 "Deck" Canteen - From Muslim Stall1, walk straight, turn left and enter the door next to the handicapped toilet. Walk straight, on your left is "Centre of Language Studies". Turn right and enter the door (near to female toilet) to lift. Go to level 6. Turn right; enter the door to staircase A.
w21z37sjrv.name: AS4 Arts and Social Science, NUS

w21zeyfcuz.address: 2 Hillside Drive Upper Serangoon Road, S(548920)
w21zeyfcuz.name: Haji Yusoff Mosque

w21z6vbfyu.directions: From the entrance, walk straight past the Straits Kitchen and lift lobby into the carpark. Once past the carpark entrance, turn right and look for door that states 'Prayer Room'.
w21z6vbfyu.name: Grand Hyatt Hotel
w21z6vbfyu.provision: Prayer Mat, Sarong, Sejadah, Songkok, Telekung, Attar, Tasbih, Al-Quran, Mirror, Chair, Slippers
w21z6vbfyu.remarks: Strictly for staffs/tenants. Male and female praying area are segregated by a sliding curtain.

w21ztnwxqz.name: Darul Ghufran Mosque
w21ztnwxqz.remarks: The brick-clad wall panels which blend with the nearby sports facilities have given way to a bluish tile after an extensive and major repair work was carried out in 1999. Built under the Mosque Building Fund in 1991, the masjid sited next to busy Tampines Central in the East can accommodate up to 4,500 people. It has daily kindergarten and madrasah classes. In the evening, the masjid is a bustle of activities as men and women attend the various religious classes offered

w21zspu0ng.name: En-Naeem Mosque
w21zspu0ng.remarks: Built under Phase Two of the Mosque Building Fund, the masjid located at the junction of Tampines Road and Hougang Ave 3, with its box-like structure and tall minaret stands out prominently, next to high-rise residential flats. Built in 1983, it serves the religious needs of residents in surrounding Hougang areas.

w21zdg08ks.name: Omar Salmah Mosque
w21zdg08ks.remarks: At one glance, it looked like any other kampung house which is slowly becoming a rare sight in a city of concrete jungle. This old generation masjid built in 1973 can accommodate up to 300 worshippers. The rather isolated masjid in the Central zone and presently caters to Television Corporation of Singapore staff nearby. Its activities include korban, Eid and Friday prayers.

w21z64sbp3.directions: Basement carpark, underneath escalator near parking lot number 250. Look out for greyish door that states 'Male's Prayer Room' or 'Female's Prayer Room'.
w21z64sbp3.name: IKEA Alexandra
w21z64sbp3.provision: Slippers, Al-Quran, Prayer mat, Chair, Fan, Tasbih, Sarong, Telekung
w21z64sbp3.remarks: There is an ablution area in the musolla. Musolla is air-conditioned. Segregated male and female praying area.

w21zv6pkhe.directions: Find toilet. After toilet, turn right to loading bay. Walk pass emergency eyewash. Enter 'hallway'. There's a partition. That's the solat place.
w21zv6pkhe.name: Pasir Ris Swimming Complex
w21zv6pkhe.remarks: Please take wuduk at toilet first. Can't remember if there's telekung for ladies.

w21z75mxh0.name: Burhani Mosque
w21z75mxh0.remarks: Sandwiched between high-rise buildings, this old generation masjid was established by the Dawoodi Bohra community in Singapore as early as 1829. Conveniently located in the Central district, it can accommodate up to 150 people. It is also frequented by office workers in the Hill Street and High Street areas.

w21zu5fyxu.name: Al-Mawaddah Mosque
w21zu5fyxu.remarks: This Phase 4 mosque was built to cater to the large demographic of young families in the Buangkok and Sengkang area. Aside from it's numerous family friendly features for the young and the old, it also boasts a number of environmentally-friendly features that are energy-conserving. Due to this mosque has attained the Greenmark Certification from the Building and Construction Authority.

w21zwqbxmq.directions: Departure Transit: Lounge South, behind Mont Blanc.
w21zwqbxmq.name: Changi Airport Terminal 3

w21zehwbgm.name: Muhajirin Mosque
w21zehwbgm.remarks:
The masjid has been re-built as part of the Singapore Islamic Hub development and was opened to public in January 2009.  

Masjid Muhajirin is the first masjid to be built under the Mosque Building Fund. Back then it was easily recognizable by its prominent dome and minaret at the entrance of the building.  Sited next to the Islamic Centre of the Islamic Religious Council of Singapore, it was completed in April 1977 with a capacity of 1400 people and serves Muslims of all ages living in Toa Payoh and Bishan.

w21z3ks609.directions: E3 Engineering - Proceed to Level 6 staircase landing near male toilet.
w21z3ks609.name: E3 Engineering, NUS

w21zg4u23n.directions:
Take lift to either Level 7 or Level R.
Musollah located at the top of each staircase within the building.
Segregated by gender.
w21zg4u23n.name: SIT@NYP
w21zg4u23n.remarks:
Level R (Top Floor), Stairs 1 - Muslimin
Level R (Top Floor), Stairs 3 - Muslimah
Level 7, Stairs 2 - Muslimah

To take ablution in nearest toilet. (Level 7)

w21z77s647.directions: Take lift from main lobby to Basement 1 and turn right. Enter exit door (to carpark B1) and turn right towards carpark. Turn left and there is a small prayer place located at the extreme end.
w21z77s647.name: Suntec City/Millenia Walk
w21z77s647.remarks: Ablution place is provided outside the room

w21z7ndgnk.directions: Women's Wing, at the staircase landing beside 24hr clinic (behind Exit door).
w21z7ndgnk.name: KK Women's and Children's Hospital

w21z74vu88.directions: Enter straircase 2 located beside unit #03-09. Enter another door (any one). Musolla is located under the staircase.
w21z74vu88.name: Adelphi
w21z74vu88.remarks: Shared male and female praying area.

w21z7ht9vs.name: Bencoolen Mosque
w21z7ht9vs.remarks: This masjid was originally built in 1845. In 2001, the mosque's site was redeveloped as part of a mixed development comprising of a commercial block and a 12-storey residential complex. The redeveloped masjid, which is part of the complex, was opened to the public in May 2004. It can accommodate about 1,100 worshippers.

w21z3kkc80.directions: E5 Engineering - Proceed to Level 4 staircase landing near elevator on E5 side.
w21z3kkc80.name: E5 Engineering, NUS

w21zec7gpg.name: Sallim Mattar Mosque
w21zec7gpg.remarks: Built during colonial times, this old generation masjid has been gazetted as a national monument. Built in 1824, it was one of the first few masjids to be built on the island. It was later rebuilt in 1920 by Swan and Maclaren who were responsible for Singapore’s other important landmarks. The masjid is a mix of Classical, Persian, Moorish and Turkish themes that form what is known as the Islamic Saracenic style. Located in the Central, it has a capacity of 2000 people and is one of the most frequented prayer venue.

w21z6v3w5c.directions: Take the lift to level 10, walk straight (about 50 metres) and turn left.
w21z6v3w5c.name: Lucky Plaza

images.caption: Ablution in toilet Near The Musholla

w21zkprrf6.directions: Take the staircase to level 2. Male's praying area is at level2, for female take another staircase beside ablution area
w21zkprrf6.name: Darul Arqam
w21zkprrf6.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Sarong, Songkok, Perfume, Mirror
w21zkprrf6.remarks: Segregated male and female praying area. Ablution place is provided.

w21zg9rb5z.name: Al-Istiqamah Mosque
w21zg9rb5z.remarks: At one glance, the masjid blends the architectural flavours of buildings in the Middle East, Nusantra and Mauritius. Its cream and turquoise-green structure stands proudly amidst the housing estate in Serangoon. One of the newest masjids under the Mosque Building Fund, it was completed in May 1999 and can accommodate up to 3300 people at any given time. Located in the Northeast, it is dubbed the multimedia masjid for its IT facilities.

w21zkr0upe.name: Khalid Mosque
w21zkr0upe.remarks: First built in 1917, this old generation masjid underwent several restorations, the most recent one in 1998. Located in the Central part of the island, its newly-restored building which comes complete with a minaret at the front porch can fill up to 2500 people. Ramadan is a busy month for the mosque as an average of 800 Muslims break their fast at the mosque daily. There are regular religious classes for children and adults.

w21zve1epq.directions: Head to the end of the Asli Village Halal Foodcourt. Musolla is located near Pizza Hut, directly behind Lotus Secret Bun.
w21zve1epq.name: Downtown East
w21zve1epq.remarks: Ablution area is located behind the musolla. Segregated male and female praying area.

w21z8f9256.directions: At the basement carpark, find the signage that states staircase L. Turn right and you will see the prayer rooms.
w21z8f9256.name: Big Box
w21z8f9256.remarks: Female prayer room might be locked. Ablution place is provided.

w21zkpgf7s.name: Wak Tanjong Mosque
w21zkpgf7s.remarks: A whitewashed structure has replaced the semi-wooden prayer hall in this redeveloped masjid located in the Central part of the island. The original masjid dated back to the year 1935. In 1998, the masjid was reopened after undergoing a major restructuring. It has a capacity of 500 people.

w21z743n5q.name: Omar Kg Melaka Mosque
w21z743n5q.remarks: The oldest masjid in Singapore, it has humble beginnings as a wooden surau way back in 1820. Monetary contributions from wealthy merchant Syed Abdullah bin Omar Aljunied made possible its rebuilding in 1855. The old generation masjid located in the Central, underwent yet another major rebuilding project several years ago in which a tall minaret with a small roof dome is added at the entrance of the mosque. With a capacity of 500 people, it is the focal point for office workers during daily and Friday prayers

w21z3k77f0.address: 4 Architecture Drive, School of Design & Environment (S), 117566
w21z3k77f0.directions: Architecture (SDE3) - Alight from SDE bus stop. Walk towards Centre For English Language Communication building. Pass it and keep walking along the pavement until you pass a bookshop on your left. Walk straight and turn right, take the lift and go to level 4. Turn right, walk pass the lecture room and turn right when you see staircase, go up and turn left. Female toilet is opposite LR422. Male toilet is opposite LR427. Musolla is at the staircase landing near to the female toilet.
w21z3k77f0.name: SDE3 Design and Environment, NUS

w21zkrvhfq.name: Darul Aman Mosque
w21zkrvhfq.remarks: A squarish minaret in this Mosque Building Fund masjid combines Malay architecture and Islamic art. Nominated for the prestigious Aga Khan Award in 1989 as an excellent example of tropical architecture, the masjid features the early pitched-roof structure commonly found in the Malay archipelago. Built in 1986, the masjid located in the East can accommodate up to 3,500 people. Besides madrasah classes, it is also popular venue for haj courses organized by travel agents. The masjid has since undergone a major addition and alteration project which was completed in 2005.

w21z9bv7dv.name: Al-Huda Mosque
w21z9bv7dv.remarks: In the past, this old generation masjid served the needs of residents living in the Malay kampung near Sixth Avenue, Bukit Timah. With resettlement, the masjid located in the Central area now serves the workers in Bukit Timah area and some residents nearby. Built in 1966, the masjid, which can accommodate up to 400 people, has undergone several renovations. Its activities are confined to daily and Friday prayers as well as celebrations of Islamic festivities.

w21z8g40t6.directions: Take lift lobby A beside McDonald's. At level 4, follow the signboards
w21z8g40t6.name: IMM Building
w21z8g40t6.provision: Slippers, Prayer Mat, Sarong, Tasbih, Al-Quran, Telekung, Fan, Chair, Water Dipper
w21z8g40t6.remarks: Segregated praying area for male and female. Ablution area is beside the toilet (outside musolla). Keys to ablution area can be taken from the musolla. Return the key after use.

w21z6ejs3z.name: Kampong Delta Mosque
w21z6ejs3z.remarks: Tucked away among Housing Board skyscraper flats, this redeveloped masjid was built on the old site of surau Delta which was first built in 1960. The new two-storey building was completed in 1995 increasing its capacity to 500 people. Its main activities are confined to daily and Friday prayers as well as celebrations of Maulid and other religious occasions.

w21z8ey1w5.name: Al-Mukminin Mosque
w21z8ey1w5.remarks: The masjid, financed by the Mosque Building Fund, was originally completed in 1987.  Located in the West, it has since undergone a major upgrading from a 2-storey to a 4-storey with basement building, which was completed in June 2006 and can now accommodate a congregation of about 4,500.  It offers a range of Islamic Learning programmes serving the needs of the residents in the nearby HDB estates .

w21z647mu7.directions: Near the toilet and cargo lift number 3. Enter the exit door (Staircase D). Turn right and proceed to the end.
w21z647mu7.name: Queensway Shopping Centre
w21z647mu7.remarks: Shared area for male and female. Ablution area beside the praying area. No fan or aircon.

w21z3s4sf2.address: S16 Science Drive 2, Faculty of Science 6 (S), 117546
w21z3s4sf2.directions: S15 Science - Alight at the Science bus stop. Walk towards S16. Turn to the left and walk towards S15. Take the lift to the 6th floor. Climb the stairs to the musolla.
w21z3s4sf2.name: S15 Science, NUS

w21z6vbw8g.directions: From hotel entrance, walk straight and turn right to the male and female toilets next to the lift lobby. There will be signs that lead to the musolla (surau). Go upstairs to the carpark. Turn left before the entrance to the carpark (enter the door that states 'surau').
w21z6vbw8g.name: Royal Plaza on Scotts
w21z6vbw8g.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Al-Quran, Tasbih, Chair, Slippers, Attar
w21z6vbw8g.remarks: There is an ablution area in the musolla. Male and female praying area are segregated by a sliding wall.

w21zwrgppu.directions: Arrival Transit: Below Gate Holdroom C1 at Arrival West.
w21zwrgppu.name: Changi Airport Terminal 1

w21zs2yvpj.name: Al-Abdul Razak Mosque
w21zs2yvpj.remarks: Nested amidst the private house of the well-to-do Malays in the East, this old generation masjid was built in 1965. The masjid with a capacity of 300, underwent minor renovations in 1997 to include additional facilities. It has a full-time imam (religious teacher) and noja (masjid helper). Religious classes are held on an ad-hoc basis. There are religious classes for the ladies every Thursday evening. Classes for the men are held every Friday evening.  Currently, major upgrading works are currently being done on the mosque.

w21z3eg0gc.address: 10 Kent Ridge Crescent, Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences (S), 119260
w21z3eg0gc.directions: AS6 FASS - Alight at the Central Library bus stop. Climb the stairs to the library. Turn to the right and walk down the walkway towards AS6. Turn to the left and enter AS6 glass door. Walk all the way to the exit door at the opposite end. Take the lift to level 5. Exit through the exit door to the staircase landing.
w21z3eg0gc.name: AS6 Arts and Social Science, NUS

w21ztq4xgf.directions: Head towards level 3 lift lobby, turn right down the hallway. Musolla is located in rooms with sliding doors
w21ztq4xgf.name: Tampines Mall
w21ztq4xgf.remarks: Segregated male and female praying area.

w21z7mntqm.name: Hajjah Fatimah Mosque
w21z7mntqm.remarks: This is another old generation masjid built from donation from a wealthy lady named Fatimah. Located in the Central district, it was completed in 1846. the masjid bears the imprint of colonial architect J T Thomson, is a charming blend of local and European architecture. It is today one of Singapore’s national monuments. Extensive renovation work was carried out several years ago in which its leaning minaret was righted. The masjid, which can accommodate up to 600 people offers religious lectures on an ad-hoc basis. It is particularly popular among office workers in Jalan Sultan area

w21zwq9zrf.directions: Departure Transit: Lounge North, near gate E, behind Aido.
w21zwq9zrf.name: Changi Airport Terminal 2

w21z9n0f49.name: Ar-Raudhah Mosque
w21z9n0f49.remarks: The masjid prides itself for having an extensive library of Islamic literatures. Built in 1993, it is located in the West and is one of the pioneer masjids offering computer facilities to Muslims. It can accommodate up to 3,000 worshippers. The masjid built under the Mosque Building Fund also has complete jenazah (death ritual) services, which is rare among the other mosques. One of its strength is its family development unit, which offers assistance in cash and kind to needy families, single parents as well as kidney patients.

w21z75x6cc.directions: Beside Quest Salon #02-27. Go straight between WAREHOUSE and BCBGMAXAZRIA.
w21z75x6cc.name: Raffles City Shopping Centre
w21z75x6cc.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Slippers, Tasbih, Al-Quran, Sarong, Songkok, Telekung
w21z75x6cc.remarks: Segregated male and female praying area. Can also be accessed from Swissotel The Stamford Hotel.

w21ztdsss3.directions: Take the staircase/elevator up to level 2. The staircase is located at the entrance to Hall 6 from level 2. (There is a door with a musolla sign to the staircase.)
w21ztdsss3.name: Singapore Expo, Hall 6
w21ztdsss3.provision: Telekung, Stool, Prayer Mat, Songkok, Sewing Kit, Mirror, Fan, Slippers
w21ztdsss3.remarks: Segregated male and female praying area.

w21z7ms6tv.name: Malabar Mosque
w21z7ms6tv.remarks: One can hardly miss this blue-tiled building adorned with gold-coloured domes located at the junction of Victoria Street and Jalan Sultan. This redeveloped masjid was first built in 1918. in 1962, it underwent major rebuilding into what it is today. Located in the Central part of the island, it serves the needs of office workers around the area and has a capacity of 1000 people. Besides religious classes, it organizes zikir sessions.

w21z7hc8wk.directions: Enter the EXIT door at lift lobby level 5. Lift lobby is located between Seahorse and V.Hive.
w21z7hc8wk.name: Plaza Singapura
w21z7hc8wk.remarks: Not an official praying area. Shared male & female area. Provision found in the hosereel cabinet.

w21z6dkhty.directions: Walk to Multi Purpose Hall, Musollah is behind the stage of multi purpose Hall.
w21z6dkhty.name: PSB Academy

w21zbu0g6f.directions: Proceed to level 4 and find the staircase beside the library
w21zbu0g6f.name: Lot One
w21zbu0g6f.remarks: Shared male and female praying area. Not an official praying area.

w21z7tjzt5.directions: From NTUC xtra, walk towards the toilet beside it. The location is at the fire exit before the toilet.
w21z7tjzt5.name: Kallang Wave Mall
w21z7tjzt5.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Slippers Provided For.
w21z7tjzt5.remarks: The area is a long corridor, so if you bring your own prayer mat, you can pray there too.

images.caption: One Long Stretch Of Solah Area

w21z3k6mfj.name: Tentera Di Raja Mosque
w21z3k6mfj.remarks: Built in 1961 by Muslim members of the British army, this old generation masjid was renamed Tentera Di Raja in recognition of their contributions. Located in the West and close to the National University of Singapore, it is distinguished by its minaret topped by a gold-painted dome. With a capacity of 1000 people, its newly-set up Youth Wing whose members are mostly undergraduates has recently embarked on a tuition scheme called EMAS (English, Maths and Science) for primary six children.

w21zvc86g5.name: Al-Istighfar Mosque
w21zvc86g5.remarks: This three-storey masjid is one of the most recent mosques built under Phase Three of the Mosque Building Fund. Completed in June 1999, it is located in the East, along Pasir Ris Drive 3. it can be recognized by its outstanding blue dome and modern yet Islamic architecture. The masjid, which can accommodate a congregation of 3300 people offers madrasah and kindergarten classes. It is a hive of activities during the evening when religious classes opened its doors to Muslims in the vicinity and also those living nearby.

w21zt88sbk.name: Al-Taqua Mosque
w21zt88sbk.remarks: In the ‘60s, this masjid was one of the important symbols for the villagers living in kampung around Bedok. Built in 1883, this single-storey masjid has gone several renovations. It now serves the handful residents living nearby as well as in the East. With a capacity of 400 worshippers, the masjid holds regular religious classes.

w21z85n79p.name: Assyakirin Mosque
w21z85n79p.remarks: One of the oldest masjids under the Mosque Building Fund, the original masjid building was opened to the public in 1978. It served the religious needs of Muslims living in the West, specifically in the Jurong area. The masjid was rebuilt to maximize land usage in order to cater to the growing needs of the residents at the neighbourhood. It was reopened on 27 Dec 2002 and can accomodate 6000 worshippers, double the capacity of the older building.

w21zkymxpw.name: Kampung Siglap Mosque
w21zkymxpw.remarks: Architects responsible for the design of this masjid built under Phase Two of the Mosque Building Fund have succeeded in preserving the architecture and ambience of a kampung. Originally, a small 80-year-old masjid, the new masjid in the same site was completed in 1992. Located in the East, it has a capacity of 3000 people. Besides madrasah classes, there is a Tahfiz Al-Quran center. A Centre of Family Development provides guidance and courses to enhance family life.

w21z7hc9v7.directions:
Located at staircase near lift, end of Spotlight outlet. Adjacent to the home furnishing section of Spotlight outlet. There's a room in between the staircase and the lifts.

Room is not entitled for prayers. However, prayers are allowed.

Wudu' to be taken at the washroom beside it.
w21z7hc9v7.name: Plaza Singapura
w21z7hc9v7.remarks: Bring own sejadah/praying mat. And telekung (for muslimah)

w21z3fz13s.name: Hang Jebat Mosque
w21z3fz13s.remarks: From a small surau, this old generation masjid has grown into what it is today. Built in 1952, this zinc-roofed masjid underwent major renovations in 1996 to expand on its prayer hall. Today it can accommodate 600 worshippers. Located in the Central part of the island, the masjid offers weekend madrasah classes to students living around Queenstown area. It also organizes zikir sessions where praises to Allah are recited.

w21z67kh5x.name: Jamek Queenstown Mosque
w21z67kh5x.remarks: Much of what was built in 1965 is retained today in this 35-year-old masjid. Located in the Central part of the island, this old generation masjid built in 1965 serves office workers around the area and has a capacity of 400 worshippers. Activities are confined to weekend madrasah classes as well as religious lectures on Thursday, Friday and Saturday.

w21z7ph8nn.name: Tasek Utara Mosque
w21z7ph8nn.remarks: In sharp contrast to a Saracenic style masjid or avant-garde looking religious structures, this old generation masjid is simple yet functional. Located at the junction of Bristol Road and Carlisle Road, this one-storey masjid can accommodate up to 120 people. Built in 1907 its main activities include daily and Friday prayers as well as occasional religious lectures.

w21zv41t0w.directions: Level 4, near the toilet at extreme end of IKEA Restaurant & Café. There are signs to lead to the location.
w21zv41t0w.name: IKEA Tampines
w21zv41t0w.remarks: There is an ablution area in the musolla. Musolla is air-conditioned. Segregated male and female praying area.

w21z3s4xe1.address: S16 Science Drive 2, Faculty of Science 6 (S), 117546
w21z3s4xe1.directions: S17 Department of Mathematics - Alight at the Science bus stop. Cross over to the department of Mathematics. Take the lift to the 4th floor. Exit the lift area, turn to the left and walk towards the Exit door. Enter the Exit door and climb the stairs to the musolla.
w21z3s4xe1.name: S17 Science, NUS

w21z6wj9s6.directions: Go down to basement 3 from the lift situated to the left of the taxi stand (outside the hotel lobby). Out the lift, turn right towards the carpark ramps. Before the carpark ramps, turn right and walk straight. Once you reach the end, turn left to the musolla.
w21z6wj9s6.name: Orchard Hotel
w21z6wj9s6.provision: Prayer Mat, Telekung, Tasbih, Fan, Chair, Al-Quran, Sarong, Songkok, Mirror
w21z6wj9s6.remarks: There is also an ablution area outside musolla. Strictly for staffs/tenants. Male and female praying areas are segregated.

w21z6v1uf6.directions: Proceed towards the public toilet. Go straight to the washing bay past the toilets. There is a small room that states "Store" for prayers.
w21z6v1uf6.name: Takashimaya at Ngee Ann City Tower A
w21z6v1uf6.provision: Slippers, Prayer Mat, Radio, Stool, Sarong, Fan
w21z6v1uf6.remarks: Strictly for staffs/tenants. Shared male and female toilet. Basins are located outside musolla.

w21z7pbs29.directions: From the lift, walk straight towards the white generators. Once in front, turn right
w21z7pbs29.name: United Square
w21z7pbs29.provision: Prayer Mat, Slippers, Al-Qur'an, Sarong, Telekung, Chair
w21z7pbs29.remarks: Shared male and female praying area. Nearest lift to musolla is located beside Efflorescence shop on level 1.

w21z790z4d.directions: Beside Texas Chicken at the Supreme Dining Area. Look for a small room (white door) which states 'Musholla'.
w21z790z4d.name: Gardens by the Bay

w21zd83mc9.name: Ba'alwie Mosque
w21zd83mc9.remarks: Built in 1952 by a prominent and well-respected imam from the Alatas family, this old generation masjid has served the needs of university undergraduates in Bukit Timah before the campus was relocated to Kent Ridge. Today, the one-storey masjid, which is located in the Central, can accommodate up to 400 worshippers for daily and Friday prayers. It is also crowded during Hari Raya prayers. On Thursday evenings, many Muslims gather for recitation of praises to Allah.

w21z66x91k.name: Jamiyah Ar-Rabitah Mosque
w21z66x91k.remarks: Redeveloped in 1985 on the same site as the old masjid, this three-storey cream structure can accommodate up to 2000 people. The first masjid was built in 1960. Today, the masjid in Central part of the island serves the needs of residents in Redhill, Tiong Bahru and Alexandra areas, besides the office workers at the nearby industrial estates. Besides madrasah and kindergarten classes, it organizes regular religious classes for the adults.

w21z774g4w.directions: Go down the escalator beside QiJi to basement. Out the glass door, turn left and left again. Head to the extreme left of the carpark. Musolla is located near carpark ramp.
w21z774g4w.name: Marina Square
w21z774g4w.provision: Prayer Mat, Chair, Sarong, Tasbih, Songkok, Al-Quran, Telekung, Fan
w21z774g4w.remarks: There is an ablution area near the musolla. Shared male and female praying area.

w21z96pf2q.name: Singapore Institute of Management, Blk A

w21z3kqsb6.directions: YIH - Take A1 from Kent Ridge MRT. Alight at YIH bus stop. Climb the stairs towards Student Service Centre to level 3.
w21z3kqsb6.name: YIH, NUS

w21zs8ub2f.name: Mydin Mosque
w21zs8ub2f.remarks: This masjid was originally completed in 1935.  Located in the Eastern part of the island, it has been rebuilt in 2001 which increased its capacity to 1,000 people.  Built to serve the needs of the neighbourhood along Changi Road, its activities are mainly religious lectures.

w21zse7f52.name: Alkaff Kampung Melayu Mosque
w21zse7f52.remarks: It is one of the few masjids, which offer religious classes for the hearing-impaired and disabled. On Sunday mornings, hundreds of children dressed in their Muslim attire complete with headgear stroll into the mosque compounds to be part of the various religious classes. The masjid, which is located in the East, can fill up to 3,000 worshippers.  Built under the Mosque Building Fund in November 1994, it replaced the older generation mosque of the same name.

w21z3mtkk7.directions: Utown - Take D1 from Kent Ridge MRT. Alight at UTown bus stop. Walk towards Education Resource Centre (ERC). Go to the 2nd floor. Go towards the exit/toilet. Enter the Exit door (stairs 3).
w21z3mtkk7.name: Utown, NUS

w21z7jryeg.name: Abdul Gafoor Mosque
w21z7jryeg.remarks: Originally built in 1859, this masjid with its unique architecture has earned the distinction as  one of Singapore's national monuments. It has an unabashed mélange of styles – a mix of Southern Indian, Moghul and Europeans influences.  Located in the Central part of Singapore, it has since been redeveloped (re-opened in 1998) with a capacity of 3000 and offers madrasah classes in Tamil besides its usual religious classes.

w21z6tt9c1.directions: Go to the hotel lift lobby and go down to basement 2. Out the lift, exit right. Turn left and left again and walk straight to carpark no. 39 - 41.
w21z6tt9c1.name: Four Seasons Hotel
w21z6tt9c1.provision: Prayer Mat, Chair, Sejadah, Mirror, Sarong, Telekung, Al-Quran
w21z6tt9c1.remarks: There is also an ablution area near the musolla. Strictly for staffs/tenants. Male and female praying areas are segregated by a sliding curtain.

w21z6h39cz.name: Mujahidin Mosque
w21z6h39cz.remarks: This is the second satellite masjid built under the Mosque Building Fund. Completed in October 1977, it is conspicuous by its cream-coloured walls and circular glass-paneled prayer hall. Instead of a dome, it has a cuboid-shaped top with semi-oval openings on all four sides. The masjid in the Central part of the island which can fill up to 3,500 people offers madrasah and kindergarten classes as well as other religious classes on a regular basis.

w21zg16qgm.address: 5140 Ang Mo Kio Central Avenue 6, S(569844)
w21zg16qgm.name: Al-Muttaqin Mosque

w21z7zpx3z.name: Khadijah Mosque
w21z7zpx3z.remarks: Built in 1920, the masjid is currently being restored to its original splendour. Named after the wealthy lady who donated $50000 in 1916 to build this masjid, restoration works was completed in 2001. The masjid located in the Central part of Singapore has a current capacity of 500 people. Its activities include computer classes, training and youth programmes as well as tuition.

w21z88eu48.name: Hasanah Mosque
w21z88eu48.remarks: First built in 1971, this masjid was redeveloped in 1993 into a four-storey building complete with elevator. Its two levels of prayer hall can accommodate up to 2500 worshippers. Located in the West, it has Internet Corner, which for a nominal annual subscription of $5, members can surf the net for $2 an hour. A newly set up Youth Wing organizes recreational activities such as camping and soccer games for the young. Muslims can benefit from its imam and muezzin courses organized on an ad-hoc basis.

w21zs849zw.name: Kassim Mosque
w21zs849zw.remarks: Combining both modern and Islamic architecture, this spanking new masjid was rebuilt to replace an old one built way back in 1924. Completed in 1999, the four-storey masjid located in the East can accommodate up to 2000 people. It is linked to Wisma Indah, a wakaf complex which houses the masjid’s office, commercial offices. Besides organizing regular religious courses for adults, the masjid also provides Internet facilities for visitors.

w21zb47cxq.name: Al-Firdaus Mosque
w21zb47cxq.remarks: This old generation masjid located in the West, off Choa Chu Kang road, was built in 1962. In 1999, the masjid, which serves the needs of the nearby residents, was rebuilt. Today, it can accommodate up to 200 people.  There are religious classes for adults in the evening.

w21z7m5crz.name: Sultan Mosque
w21z7m5crz.remarks: Built during colonial times, this old generation masjid has been gazetted as a national monument. Built in 1824, it was one of the first few masjids to be built on the island. It was later rebuilt in 1920 by Swan and Maclaren who were responsible for Singapore’s other important landmarks. The masjid is a mix of Classical, Persian, Moorish and Turkish themes that form what is known as the Islamic Saracenic style. Located in the Central, it has a capacity of 2000 people and is one of the most frequented prayer venue.

w21z3kj09p.directions: Central Forum FASS - Alight at the Central Library bus stop. Climb the stairs to the library. Turn to the right to the book drop. Go down the narrow stairs beside the book drop. The musolla is halfway between the 1st and 2nd floor.
w21z3kj09p.name: Central Forum FASS, NUS

w21zkqh73z.directions: Take the lift to level 4, turn left and enter stair A exit door. Go up to level 5 and turn left and proceed straight to the extreme end where the musolla is located. There are signs to lead to the location.
w21zkqh73z.name: Lagun Sari at OCN Building

w21z6yg6tv.name: Sheraton Towers
w21z6yg6tv.directions: Take the lift lobby carpark down to B4. Exit the door to the carpark and go down the stairs. Prayer area is at the right corner of the carpark. There is a tap next to the area.

w21z71531b.name: Al-Abrar Mosque
w21z71531b.remarks: The masjid, which bears the imprint of South Indian architecture in its narrow frontages, which are defined by two minaret-style towers, was founded in 1827. But it was only in 1855, that a formal building was set up. In 1974, the old generation masjid located in Central Singapore was gazetted as one of the national monuments. With a capacity of 500, it serves the needs of office workers in the Shenton Road area. Unlike neighbourhood masjids, which spring to life in the evening, this masjid is relatively quiet except for its occasional Tafsir Al-Quran (Al-Quran interpretation) courses.

w21zur4uu1.name: Al-Islah Mosque
w21zur4uu1.remarks: Al-Islah Mosque is the second mosque built under Phase 4 of the Mosque Building Programme. With its capacity for 4,000 congregants, Al-Islah Mosque will be able to serve the growing Muslim community in Punggol and the surrounding neighbourhoods, as well as ease the prayer space crunch on Fridays and Eid for Muslims in the eastern part of Singapore.

w21zedsj4p.name: Alkaff Upper Serangoon Mosque
w21zedsj4p.remarks: This old generation masjid sited next to Darul Libanat, a girls’ orphanage, was built in 1920. The masjid located in the Central part of the island has undergone several renovation, its most recent one in 1998, in which the prayer hall was extended to accommodate a larger congregation of 2,500 people. It serves the religious needs of the small Muslim residents in the area as well as office workers. Besides daily and Friday prayer, there are religious classes held at the masjid.

w21z7q83hz.name: Angullia Mosque
w21z7q83hz.remarks: If there is one masjid, which attracts a wide range of nationalities, it must be the Masjid Angullia. Located along one of Singapore’s busiest main roads in the Central district, the mosque is a place for devotion of shoppers across the road at Serangoon Plaza as well as shopkeepers and office workers nearby. It can accommodate 400 Muslims any one time. Built with funds from a wealthy Angullia family in 1970, it has an Indian-like minaret. Today, it is famous as a center of tabligh (activities to promote Islam).

w21zenq5jq.name: An-Nahdhah Mosque
w21zenq5jq.remarks:
This mosque is the sixth one to be built under Phase III of the Mosque Building Fund programme to serve the needs of the Muslim community around the Bishan area. The mosque can accommodate about 4,000 people and was opened to the public on 6th January 2006. 

The mosque complex also houses MUIS's Harmony Centre where visitors could learn of the Muslim Community and Islam as practiced in multi-cultural Singapore. Being the first of its kind in a Singapore mosque, the 2-storey Harmony Centre showcases exhibits, artifacts and information on Islamic civilisation and lifestyle. Contemporary issues in Islam and Inter-faith understanding will also be a feature at the Centre through talks and activities. The Centre is scheduled to be opened to all in October 2006.

w21z7ybu59.name: Haji Mohd Salleh (G) Mosque
w21z7ybu59.remarks: A historic milestone was achieved in November 1999 when its new four-storey building was officially opened after more than a year of extensive rebuilding. The original structure which dated back in 1896 was built on land donated by an individual. The masjid with its simple and modern architecture can accommodate up to 1,500 congregants.

w21z5pg1ng.name: Haji Muhammad Salleh (P) Mosque
w21z5pg1ng.remarks: Sited at the far end of Shenton Road, the masjid in its tranquil serenity is a sharp contrast to the hustle and bustle of the busy Central Business District. With a total capacity of 500, this old generation masjid, which was built in 1903, underwent several renovation and repair works. Because it is located away from residential areas, activities are confined during office hours and constitute mainly the obligatory prayers.

w21ze32wkx.name: Hajjah Rahimabi Mosque
w21ze32wkx.remarks: Built from donation by Hajjah Rahima Bee Ahmad Angullia, this masjid was redeveloped from an existing masjid, which had been around since 1960. the redeveloped masjid, which was completed in 1984, was renamed after the donor. Located in the Central part of the island, it is one of the several mosques which have pulpits decorated with woodcarvings. With a capacity of about 500 worshippers, it organizes Iqra’ and Mukaddam (Quran reading) courses.

w21z375fmt.name: Hussein Sulaiman Mosque
w21z375fmt.remarks: This old generation masjid which started as a village surau was built way back in 1902. Today, it retains much of its original architecture. Located in the Central part of the island, it occupies an area of 422 sq metre and has a capacity of 300 people. Activities are confined to daily and Friday prayers with occasional religious lectures.

w21ztq0y8t.name: Tampines Mall
w21ztq0y8t.directions: Cross the small road towards Tampines mall. Look for the toilet nearest to HnM
w21ztq0y8t.provision: Slippers, Praying Mats, Telekung, Qiblat Indicator, Wudu' Area

w21z3scdn9.name: B2 @ SIT Dover
w21z3scdn9.directions: From The Canopy (main food court), turn right at the toilet and walk along the corridor to the next toilet. The musolla is under the staircase, beside the male toilet.
w21z3scdn9.provision: Slippers, Praying Mats, Telekung, Qiblat Indicator, Quran, Fans
w21z3scdn9.remarks: If the musolla is fully occupied, you can pray at the turfed open area on mezzanine level, a few steps up outside the musolla.

w21zeq33x4.name: Admin Building Locker
w21zeq33x4.address:
Ang Mo Kio South Flyover, Singapore
1.35296, 103.85578
w21zeq33x4.directions: Find Men's Locker/Bathroom near the Row of Motorcycle Lots near the canteen. Inside the locker room, walk all the way to the end.
w21zeq33x4.provision: Slippers, Praying Mats, Wudu' Area, Fans
w21zeq33x4.remarks: This is a restricted area. You will need an escort if you are coming into this depot.
